Post ID:3735
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2005-07-13 14:08:00
Subject:Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners!!
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
http://www.ProLibertadweb.com
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________________

Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners!!

History has shown us that the power of the people, active and in motion, 
frees political prisoners. It was our united cry for freedom, international 
support and consistent national work for more than three decades that 
pressured President Carter to free the 4 Nationalist Political Prisoners in 
1978 and President Clinton to grant clemency to 12 of the Puerto Rican 
Political Prisoners in 1999.  Today, however, three Puerto Rican Political 
Prisoners, Haydee Beltran, Oscar Lopez Rivera, and Carlos Alberto Torres 
remain in U.S. jails serving punitive and excessive sentences for fighting 
for the independence and self-determination of Puerto Rico; a colony of the 
United States since 1898.  Adding your voice to the cry for freedom, justice 
and human rights now can insure that our call will be heard once again and 
will make an important contribution to obtaining justice for these freedom 
fighters.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign makes a call to all people who love freedom 
and justice to take up the challenge presented by �Millions for the Puerto 
Rican Political Prisoners!� Campaign.  Our goal is to re-energize the 
campaign to obtain the unconditional release of the Puerto Rican Political 
Prisoners by collecting one million signatures calling for their 
unconditional release.  In June of 2006, we will present the petitions 
collected to the International Community during the annual hearings of the 
United Nations Special Committee on De-colonization.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling on all freedom and justice 
loving people to support this campaign.  We propose to identify 1000 
organizations and individuals, nationally and internationally, to sponsor 
the campaign and to commit to collecting signatures within their 
organization, community, school, church, etc. Sponsoring organizations and 
individuals will receive a packet with ProLibertad literature and 100 
petitions; each petition has 10 spaces for signatures.  By working with 1000 
organizations, each taking 100 petitions at 10 signatures per page, we will 
reach our goal of Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners.

This campaign will show the international community that the movement to 
free the Puerto Rican Political is alive and thriving.  This campaign will 
allow us to educate, organize and mobilize people throughout the world. You 
can help us make this just goal a reality!  We call upon you to become an 
active part of the �Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners� 
Campaign!

Throughout the coming year ProLibertad will be organizing petition drives, 
community forums and other events to promote the campaign. Organizations and 
individuals will be invited to help in the collection of signatures, the 
dissemination of literature and to support events.  We will encourage 
sponsoring organizations to hold their own activities and initiatives during 
the year and will help to publicize, mobilize and provide support.

All sponsoring organizations and individuals who sign onto this campaign 
will be listed in all the Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners 
Campaign literature and media outreach.

To join our campaign contact us via email ProLibertad@..., or call 
us at Bronx 718-601-4751, Manhattan 212-927-9065, or New Jersey 
201-435-3244.  Send us your address and contact information and we will send 
you the �Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners� Packet and add 
you to our list to keep you updates on campaign developments.

Your organizational or individual donations are also needed to make the 
�Millions for the Puerto Rican Prisoners� Campaign a success. Tax-deductible 
donations may be sent to: IFCO/ProLibertad, 402 West 145th Street, New York, 
New York 10033. Please indicate Millions in 2006 in the memo section of your 
check or money order.

Our Cry For Freedom And Justice Must Be Heard!
The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign

Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners!!

History has shown us that the power of the people, active and in motion,

Campaign literature and media outreach.

us at Bronx 718-601-4751, Manhattan 212-927-9065, or New Jersey 
201-435-3244.  Send us your address and contact information and we will send 
you the �Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners� Packet and add 
you to our list to keep you updates on campaign developments.

Your organizational or individual donations are also needed to make the 
�Millions for the Puerto Rican Prisoners� Campaign a success. Tax-deductible 
donations may be sent to: IFCO/ProLibertad, 402 West 145th Street, New York, 
New York 10033. Please indicate Millions in 2006 in the memo section of your 
check or money order.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign

PUERTO RICAN POLITICAL PRISONERS" campaign; there is another way to support 
our new campaign you could add your name to our online UN Petition.

Please click on to the following link: 
http://www.petitiononline.com/ProLibUN/petition.html

Join the "MILLIONS FOR THE PUERTO RICAN POLITICAL PRISONERS" campaign!!  
Sign our online petition, forward it out through your listserves, and help 
us make our goal.  Also, read our call below this message and let us know if 
you want us to send you a MILLIONS FOR THE PUERTO RICAN POLITICAL PRISONERS 
packet!!
______________________________________________________________________________

Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners!!

History has shown us that the power of the people, active and in motion,
frees political prisoners. It was our united cry for freedom, international
support and consistent national work for more than three decades that
pressured President Carter to free the 4 Nationalist Political Prisoners in
1978 and President Clinton to grant clemency to 12 of the Puerto Rican
Political Prisoners in 1999.  Today, however, three Puerto Rican Political
Prisoners, Haydee Beltran, Oscar Lopez Rivera, and Carlos Alberto Torres
remain in U.S. jails serving punitive and excessive sentences for fighting
for the independence and self-determination of Puerto Rico; a colony of the
United States since 1898.  Adding your voice to the cry for freedom, justice
and human rights now can insure that our call will be heard once again and
will make an important contribution to obtaining justice for these freedom
fighters.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign makes a call to all people who love freedom
and justice to take up the challenge presented by �Millions for the Puerto
Rican Political Prisoners!� Campaign.  Our goal is to re-energize the
campaign to obtain the unconditional release of the Puerto Rican Political
Prisoners by collecting one million signatures calling for their
unconditional release.  In June of 2006, we will present the petitions
collected to the International Community during the annual hearings of the
United Nations Special Committee on De-colonization.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling on all freedom and justice
loving people to support this campaign.  We propose to identify 1000
organizations and individuals, nationally and internationally, to sponsor
the campaign and to commit to collecting signatures within their
organization, community, school, church, etc. Sponsoring organizations and
individuals will receive a packet with ProLibertad literature and 100
petitions; each petition has 10 spaces for signatures.  By working with 1000
organizations, each taking 100 petitions at 10 signatures per page, we will
reach our goal of Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners.

This campaign will show the international community that the movement to
free the Puerto Rican Political is alive and thriving.  This campaign will
allow us to educate, organize and mobilize people throughout the world. You
can help us make this just goal a reality!  We call upon you to become an
active part of the �Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners�
Campaign!

Throughout the coming year ProLibertad will be organizing petition drives,
community forums and other events to promote the campaign. Organizations and
individuals will be invited to help in the collection of signatures, the
dissemination of literature and to support events.  We will encourage
sponsoring organizations to hold their own activities and initiatives during
the year and will help to publicize, mobilize and provide support.

All sponsoring organizations and individuals who sign onto this campaign
will be listed in all the Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners
Campaign literature and media outreach.

To join our campaign contact us via email ProLibertad@..., or call
us at Bronx 718-601-4751, Manhattan 212-927-9065, or New Jersey
201-435-3244.  Send us your address and contact information and we will send
you the �Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners� Packet and add
you to our list to keep you updates on campaign developments.

Your organizational or individual donations are also needed to make the
�Millions for the Puerto Rican Prisoners� Campaign a success. Tax-deductible
donations may be sent to: IFCO/ProLibertad, 402 West 145th Street, New York,
New York 10033. Please indicate Millions in 2006 in the memo section of your
check or money order.

Our Cry For Freedom And Justice Must Be Heard!
The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign

Post ID:3741
Sender:"R_Luke" <48c51821bae8bedfcd027b8aafc80ba7@...>
Post Date/Time:2005-07-20 01:32:35
Subject:The Internet is Awesome For Relationships
Message:

Thought I should pass on my knowledge to all you guys (and gals) on here. I know like heaps of men I am pretty shy when it comes to going up to someone. I've tried a few different places (clubs, bars, etc) but never seem to have too much luck. Anyway, a couple of weeks ago I joined up to http://www.findyourpartner.info/zubv and I have to say I am already getting excited. I was beginning to think I'd end up being alone for ever, but already been talking to a few interestedladies on there. Anyway, if you're like me it comes highly recommended!

Post ID:3744

Subject:Hello, I saw you in a YAHOO! group. Want to chat?
Message:

I have a profile with photos on this dating site which only serves BBW,
BHM and FA. Register only 2 pages and send me a wink here! :)

http://www.geocities.com/sexybbwsingles/
http://www.pluslovers.zu5.net





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3745
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2005-08-03 10:53:50
Subject:Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
http://www.ProLibertadweb.com
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________________

Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners!!

History has shown us that the power of the people, active and in motion,
frees political prisoners. It was our united cry for freedom, international
support and consistent national work for more than three decades that
pressured President Carter to free the 4 Nationalist Political Prisoners in
1978 and President Clinton to grant clemency to 12 of the Puerto Rican
Political Prisoners in 1999.  Today, however, three Puerto Rican Political
Prisoners, Haydee Beltran, Oscar Lopez Rivera, and Carlos Alberto Torres
remain in U.S. jails serving punitive and excessive sentences for fighting
for the independence and self-determination of Puerto Rico; a colony of the
United States since 1898.  Adding your voice to the cry for freedom, justice
and human rights now can insure that our call will be heard once again and
will make an important contribution to obtaining justice for these freedom
fighters.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign makes a call to all people who love freedom
and justice to take up the challenge presented by �Millions for the Puerto
Rican Political Prisoners!� Campaign.  Our goal is to re-energize the
campaign to obtain the unconditional release of the Puerto Rican Political
Prisoners by collecting one million signatures calling for their
unconditional release.  In June of 2006, we will present the petitions
collected to the International Community during the annual hearings of the
United Nations Special Committee on De-colonization.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling on all freedom and justice
loving people to support this campaign.  We propose to identify 1000
organizations and individuals, nationally and internationally, to sponsor
the campaign and to commit to collecting signatures within their
organization, community, school, church, etc. Sponsoring organizations and
individuals will receive a packet with ProLibertad literature and 100
petitions; each petition has 10 spaces for signatures.  By working with 1000
organizations, each taking 100 petitions at 10 signatures per page, we will
reach our goal of Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners.

This campaign will show the international community that the movement to
free the Puerto Rican Political is alive and thriving.  This campaign will
allow us to educate, organize and mobilize people throughout the world. You
can help us make this just goal a reality!  We call upon you to become an
active part of the �Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners�
Campaign!

Throughout the coming year ProLibertad will be organizing petition drives,
community forums and other events to promote the campaign. Organizations and
individuals will be invited to help in the collection of signatures, the
dissemination of literature and to support events.  We will encourage
sponsoring organizations to hold their own activities and initiatives during
the year and will help to publicize, mobilize and provide support.

All sponsoring organizations and individuals who sign onto this campaign
will be listed in all the Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners
Campaign literature and media outreach.

To join our campaign contact us via email ProLibertad@..., or call
us at Bronx 718-601-4751, Manhattan 212-927-9065, or New Jersey
201-435-3244.  Send us your address and contact information and we will send
you the �Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners� Packet and add
you to our list to keep you updates on campaign developments.

Your organizational or individual donations are also needed to make the
�Millions for the Puerto Rican Prisoners� Campaign a success. Tax-deductible
donations may be sent to: IFCO/ProLibertad, 402 West 145th Street, New York,
New York 10033. Please indicate Millions in 2006 in the memo section of your
check or money order.

Our Cry For Freedom And Justice Must Be Heard!
The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign

Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners!!

History has shown us that the power of the people, active and in motion,
frees political prisoners. It was our united cry for freedom, international
support and consistent national work for more than three decades that
pressured President Carter to free the 4 Nationalist Political Prisoners in

Political Prisoners in 1999.  Today, however, three Puerto Rican Political
Prisoners, Haydee Beltran, Oscar Lopez Rivera, and Carlos Alberto Torres
remain in U.S. jails serving punitive and excessive sentences for fighting
for the independence and self-determination of Puerto Rico; a colony of the
United States since 1898.  Adding your voice to the cry for freedom, justice
and human rights now can insure that our call will be heard once again and
will make an important contribution to obtaining justice for these freedom
fighters.

Rican Political Prisoners!� Campaign.  Our goal is to re-energize the
campaign to obtain the unconditional release of the Puerto Rican Political
Prisoners by collecting one million signatures calling for their
unconditional release.  In June of 2006, we will present the petitions
collected to the International Community during the annual hearings of the
United Nations Special Committee on De-colonization.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling on all freedom and justice
loving people to support this campaign.  We propose to identify 1000
organizations and individuals, nationally and internationally, to sponsor
the campaign and to commit to collecting signatures within their
organization, community, school, church, etc. Sponsoring organizations and
individuals will receive a packet with ProLibertad literature and 100
petitions; each petition has 10 spaces for signatures.  By working with 1000
organizations, each taking 100 petitions at 10 signatures per page, we will
reach our goal of Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners.

This campaign will show the international community that the movement to
free the Puerto Rican Political is alive and thriving.  This campaign will
allow us to educate, organize and mobilize people throughout the world. You
can help us make this just goal a reality!  We call upon you to become an
active part of the �Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners�
Campaign!

Throughout the coming year ProLibertad will be organizing petition drives,
community forums and other events to promote the campaign. Organizations and
individuals will be invited to help in the collection of signatures, the
dissemination of literature and to support events.  We will encourage
sponsoring organizations to hold their own activities and initiatives during
the year and will help to publicize, mobilize and provide support.

All sponsoring organizations and individuals who sign onto this campaign
will be listed in all the Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners
Campaign literature and media outreach.

To join our campaign contact us via email ProLibertad@..., or call
us at Bronx 718-601-4751, Manhattan 212-927-9065, or New Jersey
201-435-3244.  Send us your address and contact information and we will send
you the �Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners� Packet and add
you to our list to keep you updates on campaign developments.

Your organizational or individual donations are also needed to make the
�Millions for the Puerto Rican Prisoners� Campaign a success. Tax-deductible
donations may be sent to: IFCO/ProLibertad, 402 West 145th Street, New York,
New York 10033. Please indicate Millions in 2006 in the memo section of your
check or money order.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign

Victory for the former Puerto Rican political prisoners  Most ex-prisoners 
have parole restrictions terminated

By Jan Susler, Posted Tuesday, August 2, 2005

On Tuesday, July 26, 2005, the United States Parole Commission issued 
rulings terminating supervision for Edwin Cort�s, Elizam Escobar, Ricardo 
Jim�nez, Adolfo Matos, Dylcia Pag�n, Alberto Rodr�guez, and Alejandrina 
Torres. After 16 and 20 years in prison, followed by five years and 10 
months of successful integration into civil society, they can now live their 
lives without government restriction. Not so for Lucy Rodr�guez and Carmen 
Valent�n. As for Carmen Valent�n, the commission is sending her case back 
for another hearing based on tardy and irrelevant input from the FBI. As for 
Lucy Rodr�guez, the commission erroneously interpreted her absence from her 
hearing as a waiver of consideration of her case. We will work to ensure 
that their supervision is likewise terminated.

The Parole Commission's ruling comes as the result of three days of hearings 
in February, during which evidence demonstrated that the former political 
prisoners are highly respected members of the society whose lives and 
careers were adversely affected by the illogical and unjust restrictions of 
supervision. In addition to evidence that the FBI closed its investigation 
of the FALN in June of 2004, the probation officers who supervised the nine 
testified that there is no ongoing law enforcement investigation, and that 
all nine were leading productive and law abiding lives since the 1999 
presidential commutation of their sentences. Leading the evidence to support 
termination of supervision was a letter from the Governor of Puerto Rico, 
An�bal Acevedo Vil�, who said, "As expressed to Chairman Reilly from the 
[Parole] Commission on August 2004, as Resident Commissioner in Washington I 
felt then, as I do now as Governor, that the above mentioned prisoners 
should not be subjected to supervision as part of the commutation of their 
sentences. The productive lives they have led since their release speaks for 
itself." Other testimony came from all four Puerto Rican members of 
Congress: Jose Serrano, Luis Gutierrez, Nydia Velazquez, and Luis Fortuno, 
as well as from leaders of civil society included Julio Fontanet, President 
of the Colegio de Abogados de Puerto Rico (Puerto Rican Bar Association) and 
Rev. Heriberto Mart�nez, President of the Concilio de Iglesias (National 
Council of Churches). The Commission also heard from other prominent 
spokespeople such as Dr. Teresa Ti�, Executive Director of the Puerto Rican 
Institute of Culture; Dr. Marimar Ben�tez, Chancellor of the Puerto Rican 
School of Fine Arts; and other academic, business and community leaders.

The former prisoners will continue to live their lives committed to the 
independence of their country, caring for their parents, children and 
grandchildren; supporting themselves; and contributing to the betterment of 
society, without the intrusion and restrictions of supervision. Appreciative 
of the support they have always received from the Puerto Rican people and 
other human rights advocates, they urge their supporters to work for the 
release of the remaining Puerto Rican political prisoners Oscar Lopez Rivera 
and Carlos Alberto Torres.

Jan Susler
Attorney for Edwin Cort�s, Elizam Escobar, Ricardo Jim�nez, Adolfo Matos, 
Dylcia Pag�n, Alberto Rodr�guez, Alicia Rodr�guez, Ida Luz (Lucy) Rodr�guez, 
Luis Rosa, Alejandrina Torres, Carmen Valent�n, Oscar Lopez Rivera and 
Carlos Alberto Torres
People's Law Office
1180 N. Milwaukee
Chicago, IL 60622
773/235-0070 ext 118

Victory for the former Puerto Rican political prisoners  Most ex-prisoners 
have parole restrictions terminated

By Jan Susler, Posted Tuesday, August 2, 2005

On Tuesday, July 26, 2005, the United States Parole Commission issued 
rulings terminating supervision for Edwin Cort�s, Elizam Escobar, Ricardo 
Jim�nez, Adolfo Matos, Dylcia Pag�n, Alberto Rodr�guez, and Alejandrina 
Torres. After 16 and 20 years in prison, followed by five years and 10 
months of successful integration into civil society, they can now live their 
lives without government restriction. Not so for Lucy Rodr�guez and Carmen 
Valent�n. As for Carmen Valent�n, the commission is sending her case back 
for another hearing based on tardy and irrelevant input from the FBI. As for 
Lucy Rodr�guez, the commission erroneously interpreted her absence from her 
hearing as a waiver of consideration of her case. We will work to ensure 
that their supervision is likewise terminated.

The Parole Commission's ruling comes as the result of three days of hearings 
in February, during which evidence demonstrated that the former political 
prisoners are highly respected members of the society whose lives and 
careers were adversely affected by the illogical and unjust restrictions of 
supervision. In addition to evidence that the FBI closed its investigation 
of the FALN in June of 2004, the probation officers who supervised the nine 
testified that there is no ongoing law enforcement investigation, and that 
all nine were leading productive and law abiding lives since the 1999 
presidential commutation of their sentences. Leading the evidence to support 
termination of supervision was a letter from the Governor of Puerto Rico, 
An�bal Acevedo Vil�, who said, "As expressed to Chairman Reilly from the 
[Parole] Commission on August 2004, as Resident Commissioner in Washington I 
felt then, as I do now as Governor, that the above mentioned prisoners 
should not be subjected to supervision as part of the commutation of their 
sentences. The productive lives they have led since their release speaks for 
itself." Other testimony came from all four Puerto Rican members of 
Congress: Jose Serrano, Luis Gutierrez, Nydia Velazquez, and Luis Fortuno, 
as well as from leaders of civil society included Julio Fontanet, President 
of the Colegio de Abogados de Puerto Rico (Puerto Rican Bar Association) and 
Rev. Heriberto Mart�nez, President of the Concilio de Iglesias (National 
Council of Churches). The Commission also heard from other prominent 
spokespeople such as Dr. Teresa Ti�, Executive Director of the Puerto Rican 
Institute of Culture; Dr. Marimar Ben�tez, Chancellor of the Puerto Rican 
School of Fine Arts; and other academic, business and community leaders.

The former prisoners will continue to live their lives committed to the 
independence of their country, caring for their parents, children and 
grandchildren; supporting themselves; and contributing to the betterment of 
society, without the intrusion and restrictions of supervision. Appreciative 
of the support they have always received from the Puerto Rican people and 
other human rights advocates, they urge their supporters to work for the 
release of the remaining Puerto Rican political prisoners Oscar Lopez Rivera 
and Carlos Alberto Torres.

Jan Susler
Attorney for Edwin Cort�s, Elizam Escobar, Ricardo Jim�nez, Adolfo Matos, 
Dylcia Pag�n, Alberto Rodr�guez, Alicia Rodr�guez, Ida Luz (Lucy) Rodr�guez, 
Luis Rosa, Alejandrina Torres, Carmen Valent�n, Oscar Lopez Rivera and 
Carlos Alberto Torres
People's Law Office
1180 N. Milwaukee
Chicago, IL 60622
773/235-0070 ext 118

Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners!!

History has shown us that the power of the people, active and in motion,
frees political prisoners. It was our united cry for freedom, international
support and consistent national work for more than three decades that
pressured President Carter to free the 4 Nationalist Political Prisoners in
1978 and President Clinton to grant clemency to 12 of the Puerto Rican
Political Prisoners in 1999.  Today, however, three Puerto Rican Political
Prisoners, Haydee Beltran, Oscar Lopez Rivera, and Carlos Alberto Torres
remain in U.S. jails serving punitive and excessive sentences for fighting
for the independence and self-determination of Puerto Rico; a colony of the
United States since 1898.  Adding your voice to the cry for freedom, justice
and human rights now can insure that our call will be heard once again and
will make an important contribution to obtaining justice for these freedom
fighters.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign makes a call to all people who love freedom
and justice to take up the challenge presented by �Millions for the Puerto
Rican Political Prisoners!� Campaign.  Our goal is to re-energize the
campaign to obtain the unconditional release of the Puerto Rican Political
Prisoners by collecting one million signatures calling for their
unconditional release.  In June of 2006, we will present the petitions
collected to the International Community during the annual hearings of the
United Nations Special Committee on De-colonization.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling on all freedom and justice
loving people to support this campaign.  We propose to identify 1000
organizations and individuals, nationally and internationally, to sponsor
the campaign and to commit to collecting signatures within their
organization, community, school, church, etc. Sponsoring organizations and
individuals will receive a packet with ProLibertad literature and 100
petitions; each petition has 10 spaces for signatures.  By working with 1000
organizations, each taking 100 petitions at 10 signatures per page, we will
reach our goal of Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners.

This campaign will show the international community that the movement to
free the Puerto Rican Political is alive and thriving.  This campaign will
allow us to educate, organize and mobilize people throughout the world. You
can help us make this just goal a reality!  We call upon you to become an
active part of the �Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners�
Campaign!

Throughout the coming year ProLibertad will be organizing petition drives,
community forums and other events to promote the campaign. Organizations and
individuals will be invited to help in the collection of signatures, the
dissemination of literature and to support events.  We will encourage
sponsoring organizations to hold their own activities and initiatives during
the year and will help to publicize, mobilize and provide support.

All sponsoring organizations and individuals who sign onto this campaign
will be listed in all the Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners
Campaign literature and media outreach.

To join our campaign contact us via email ProLibertad@..., or call
us at Bronx 718-601-4751, Manhattan 212-927-9065, or New Jersey
201-435-3244.  Send us your address and contact information and we will send
you the �Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners� Packet and add
you to our list to keep you updates on campaign developments.

Your organizational or individual donations are also needed to make the
�Millions for the Puerto Rican Prisoners� Campaign a success. Tax-deductible
donations may be sent to: IFCO/ProLibertad, 402 West 145th Street, New York,
New York 10033. Please indicate Millions in 2006 in the memo section of your
check or money order.

Our Cry For Freedom And Justice Must Be Heard!
The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign

Post ID:3751
Sender:"FreetheCuban5 LibertadparalosCinco" <freethecuban5@...>
Post Date/Time:2005-08-08 12:33:36
Subject:Aug. 30th Mission Against Terror
Message:

The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
http://www.freethecuban5.com
Freethecuban5@...
Free the Cuban 5 Hotline: 718-601-4751

*******************************************************************************

Download the August edition of the Project Newsletter:
http://www.freethecuban5.com/JF5AugustNewsletter.pdf

*******************************************************************************
Tuesday August 30th at 7:30pm
The Brecht Forum 451 West St. NYC
Phone: 212-242-4201

IF YOU MISSED MISSION AGAINST TERROR IN JUNE AND JULY, THEN JOIN US IN
AUGUST!!

Mission Against Terror (Directors Bernie Dwyer and Roberto Ruiz Rebo/ 48
minutes/2004) tells the story of the 5 Cubans, who are currently imprisoned
in U.S. jails because they were working for to expose ultra-right terrorist
groups in Miami and stop them from carrying out violent actions against the
Cuban people.

This film screening is a part of the Brecht Forum's Black August Film
Series!!  http://www.brechtforum.org

*******************************************************************************

Sign the Cuban 5 Petition "Family Visitation Petition" prepared by the
Jericho Movement!!

Sign the Petition and get your friends and family to do so as well.  Also,
do not forget to send a letter to Attorney Alberto Gonzalez!!  Go to our
National Visa Campaign Page on our website and send out your support
letter!!

IT IS EXTREMELY IMPORTANT THAT WE KEEP THE PRESSURE UP ON U.S. ATTORNEY
GENERAL ALBERTO GONZALEZ; SEND THE LETTER OUT AND FORWARD IT THROUGH YOUR 
EMAIL ADDRESS BOOKS!!

www.PetitionOnline.com/cuban5/petition.html

Post ID:3753
Sender:"FreetheCuban5 LibertadparalosCinco" <freethecuban5@...>
Post Date/Time:2005-08-09 14:59:21
Subject:Court of Appeals approve new Trail for the Cuban 5!!
Message:

The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
http://www.freethecuban5.com
Freethecuban5@...
Free the Cuban 5 Hotline: 718-601-4751

*******************************************************************************

Download the August edition of the Project Newsletter:
http://www.freethecuban5.com/JF5AugustNewsletter.pdf

*******************************************************************************

Announcement from the National Committee to Free the Cuban Five
Today, August 9, after more than one year of weighing the
evidence, the 11th Circuit Court of a Appeals vacated the
trial court's ruling against the Cuban Five and ordered a
new trial with a change of venue. This is a sensational
victory for the Five, the Cuban people, and the
international people's movement that supports them! The
Five will now receive a new trial in a place other than
Miami. This blow to the U.S. government undeniably was made
possible by the hard work and growing support of
progressive, justice-loving people in the U.S. and all over
the world.

The National Committee to Free the Cuban Five is holding a
telephone press conference today with the Five's attorney,
Leonard Weinglass, the coordinator of the National
Committee to Free the Cuban Five, Gloria La Riva,
A.N.S.W.E.R. Coalition Coordinator, Brian Becker, and other
activists and legal experts to discuss this landmark
victory. We will send more information as soon as we have
it. In the meantime, call 323-464-1636 with questions.
The Five are one big step closer to freedom. Let's continue
the struggle and ensure total victory. Free the Cuban Five!
U.S. Hands Off Cuba!

Volver�n! They will return!

National Committee to Free the Cuban Five
For more info call 323-464-1636 or e-mail freethefivela@....

The convictions of the Cuban Five have been overturned
by the federal appellate court in Atlanta, Georgia.
The request for change of venue has been granted and
the case is being sent back for retrial OUTSIDE MIAMI.
This is what the defense campaign has always sought
There will be a news conference in San Francisco
at the offices of FREE THE FIVE at 10:00 AM today

.
Speakers:
Gloria LaRiva, Free The Five
Leonard Weinglass, Attorney for Gerardo Hernandez
Richard Klugh, Attorney from Public Defenders Office
Miami, Florida.

More details as soon as we have them.
NOTE THIS FROM ATTORNEY LEONARD WEINGLASS
During the trial, the attorneys for the Five requested a
change of venue from Miami to another city five times. The
judge denied each request. In December 2001, two of the
Five were sentenced to life in prison, one to 19 years, and
one, to 15 years. Gerardo Hernandez received two life
terms.

Why is it not possible for Cuban nationals like the
Five to receive a fair trial in Miami ? What role do
anti-Cuban terrorists play?

Miami is the one city in the US where the Five
certainly could not receive a fair trial. There are
approximately 650,000 Cubans who live there in exile.
They control the local press and the media, they occupy the
public offices, and they are the major business figures in
the area. These individuals and institutions are highly
influential, and they all have one thing in common: they
take a hard line on Cuba . Miami is a different place than
every other city in the US . A portion of the exile
community has engaged in terrorism against Cuba for
decades. Violence against Cuba is heralded in small, but
vocal, circles in Miami .

For instance, in Miami , the
terrorist Orlando Bosch walks the streets a free man. The
US Justice Department once labeled Bosch the most dangerous
terrorist in the Western Hemisphere . He was responsible
for bombing a Cuban passenger airline in mid-flight in
1976, killing all 73 passengers on board. Hard-line exiles
and their supporters play a large role in shaping public
opinion and debate in Miami . To try the Five in Miami was
a clear violation of their right to have a trial free of
outside influences that were prejudiced against them. The
venue of the trial should have been moved out of Miami to
another location.
DETAILS

http://makeashorterlink.com/?W23F3249B
VOLVERAN!  They will return!
Free The Five!





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3754
Sender:"FreetheCuban5 LibertadparalosCinco" <freethecuban5@...>
Post Date/Time:2005-08-09 15:00:38
Subject:Court of Appeals approve new Trail for the Cuban 5!!
Message:

The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
http://www.freethecuban5.com
Freethecuban5@...
Free the Cuban 5 Hotline: 718-601-4751

*******************************************************************************

Download the August edition of the Project Newsletter:
http://www.freethecuban5.com/JF5AugustNewsletter.pdf

*******************************************************************************

Announcement from the National Committee to Free the Cuban Five
Today, August 9, after more than one year of weighing the
evidence, the 11th Circuit Court of a Appeals vacated the
trial court's ruling against the Cuban Five and ordered a
new trial with a change of venue. This is a sensational
victory for the Five, the Cuban people, and the
international people's movement that supports them! The
Five will now receive a new trial in a place other than
Miami. This blow to the U.S. government undeniably was made
possible by the hard work and growing support of
progressive, justice-loving people in the U.S. and all over
the world.

The National Committee to Free the Cuban Five is holding a
telephone press conference today with the Five's attorney,
Leonard Weinglass, the coordinator of the National
Committee to Free the Cuban Five, Gloria La Riva,
A.N.S.W.E.R. Coalition Coordinator, Brian Becker, and other
activists and legal experts to discuss this landmark
victory. We will send more information as soon as we have
it. In the meantime, call 323-464-1636 with questions.
The Five are one big step closer to freedom. Let's continue
the struggle and ensure total victory. Free the Cuban Five!
U.S. Hands Off Cuba!

Volver�n! They will return!

For more info call 323-464-1636 or e-mail freethefivela@....

Subject:Looking for your perfect match?
Message:

I know a couple of friends already who have met a few nice honey�s off of this kind of stuff (here is the site they use: http://www.singleppl.info/jwme , but what do you think? I think it is pretty cool from what I saw at my friend�s house, and am thinking of signing up later today. Basically it's a regular personalssite, but with an instant message and Webcam system built in. Basically you join their chat-room on their site it gives you a link to those people online in the chat-room, their location, their picture, etc and at one click you can start chatting to them over Webcam (even if you don't have one). Pretty nifty stuff I think!

Post ID:3758
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2005-08-14 17:03:31
Subject:Sept. 8th: Justice for Tito Kayak!!
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
http://www.ProLibertadweb.com
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________________

DOWNLOAD THE AUGUST EDITION OF EL COQUI LIBRE; ProLibertad's newsletter:
http://www.prolibertadweb.com/eclAugust2005.pdf
_______________________________________________________________________________

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign has debuted our "MILLIONS FOR THE
PUERTO RICAN POLITICAL PRISONERS" campaign; there is another way to support
our new campaign you could add your name to our online UN Petition.

Please click on to the following link:
http://www.petitiononline.com/ProLibUN/petition.html

Join the "MILLIONS FOR THE PUERTO RICAN POLITICAL PRISONERS" campaign!!
Sign our online petition, forward it out through your listserves, and help
us make our goal. Also, read our call below this message and let us know if
you want us to send you a MILLIONS FOR THE PUERTO RICAN POLITICAL PRISONERS
packet!!
_______________________________________________________________________________

THURSDAY SEPTEMBER 8TH AT 9AM!!  JUSTICE FOR TITO KAYAK!!

Join ProLibertad, Ismael Guadalupe Ortiz (Long time Vieques Activist), and 
the friends of Tito Kayak in NYC, as we support our brother Alberto �Tito 
Kayak� DeJesus!!

Tito Kayak, a Puerto Rican environmentalist and civil disobedient, was 
arrested on Monday June 13th, 2005 for  attempting to lower the United 
Nations flag and replacing it with the Puerto Rican flag; this was an 
another attempt to call attention to the colonial condition of Puerto Rico 
and to the contamination on the island of Vieques!!

As many of you remember, Tito Kayak was responsible for hanging the Puerto 
Rican and Vieques flags from the Statue of Liberty on November 2001.  Tito 
was sentenced to jail for this act of civil disobedience and served his time 
in New York City and Puerto Rico.

This latest civil disobedience took place during the United Nations 
De-Colonization Hearings, as a delegation from Puerto Rico and throughout 
the United States testified for the liberation of Puerto Rico from U.S. 
colonialism.

Tito was released from prison on Tuesday June 14th; Tito has a hearing on 
Thursday Sept. 8th!!  Tito could be facing 3-7 years for his endangerment 
charge and 90 days for trespassing!!

Tito needs our support!!  Take the day off from Work!!  We have to pack the 
court house and make sure that this brother receives justice!!

Thursday Sept. 8th at 9am
100 Centre St. Manhattan Criminal Court
Subway: 4, 5, 6, J, M to Chambers St./Brooklyn Bridge; A, C, E to Chambers 
St.; R, N to Canal St.

Post ID:3761
Sender:"FreetheCuban5 LibertadparalosCinco" <freethecuban5@...>
Post Date/Time:2005-08-15 13:46:49
Subject:Aug. 30th Mission Against Terror
Message:

The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
http://www.freethecuban5.com
Freethecuban5@...
Free the Cuban 5 Hotline: 718-601-4751

*******************************************************************************
Tuesday August 30th at 7:30pm
The Brecht Forum 451 West St. NYC
Phone: 212-242-4201

IF YOU MISSED MISSION AGAINST TERROR IN JUNE AND JULY, THEN JOIN US IN
AUGUST!!

Mission Against Terror (Directors Bernie Dwyer and Roberto Ruiz Rebo/ 48
minutes/2004) tells the story of the 5 Cubans, who are currently imprisoned
in U.S. jails because they were working for to expose ultra-right terrorist
groups in Miami and stop them from carrying out violent actions against the
Cuban people.

This film screening is a part of the Brecht Forum's Black August Film
Series!!  http://www.brechtforum.org

*******************************************************************************

Sign the Cuban 5 Petition "Family Visitation Petition" prepared by the 
Jericho Movement!!

Sign the Petition and get your friends and family to do so as well.  Also,
do not forget to send a letter to Attorney Alberto Gonzalez!!  Go to our
National Visa Campaign Page on our website and send out your support
letter!!

IT IS EXTREMELY IMPORTANT THAT WE KEEP THE PRESSURE UP ON U.S. ATTORNEY
GENERAL ALBERTO GONZALEZ; SEND THE LETTER OUT AND FORWARD IT THROUGH YOUR 
EMAIL
ADDRESS BOOKS!!

www.PetitionOnline.com/cuban5/petition.html

*****************************************************************************

Washington's decades-long effort to overthrow the Revolution in
Cuba has suffered a powerful defeat in the ruling of the Atlanta
federal appellate court throwing out the convictions of the Five.
Alarc�n advises Washington to cut its losses by freeing them now.
The authoritative nature of the court's judgement flows from its
conservative nature as a bastion of the political establishment.

("In no way is the finding a consequence of any action against the
United States by the Cuban government. The judges who analyzed the
case are not agents of our country, or revolutionaries, or
sympathizers with the Cuban Revolution. In the document that they
presented in an elegant language, they define their distance in
relation to Cuba," Alarcon explains.

*****************************************************************************

http://www.granma.cu/ingles/2005/agosto/vier12/34juicio.html
GRANMA INTERNATIONAL
Havana. August 12, 2005

Ricardo Alarc�n: if the Five have a retrial, it will turn into a
Nuremberg for the U.S.

� Reiterates in a press conference that in line with the Atlanta
Court ruling, they should be released immediately

BY MARIA JULIA MAYORAL
Granma daily special correspondents

CARACAS, August 11.�Ricardo Alarc�n, president of the National
Assembly of People�s Power, today asked participants in the 16th
World Festival of Youth and Students to raise their voices to demand
the immediate and unconditional release of the five Cuban heroes,
anti-terrorist fighters kidnapped by the U.S. government.

Antonio Guerrero, Fernando Gonz�lez, Gerardo Hern�ndez, Ram�n
Laba�ino and Ren� Gonz�lez never committed the crimes for which they
were imprisoned in the United States seven years ago, and now that
truth has been recognized by the three judges appointed by the
Eleventh Circuit Atlanta Court of Appeals to review the case.

�On August 9 the judges publicly announced their unanimous decision
to overturn the sentences and order a retrial for our compatriots,
who have the right to an impartial trial in a non-hostile atmosphere.
However, the Five are still incarcerated in maximum-security prisons.
What we would like is for the fullest, most generous and most
vigorous will to emerge from this Festival so that the Washington
authorities know that many people in the world know that they are
holding kidnapped five anti-terrorist combatants; that the U.S.
General Attorney�s Office is flooded with letters, faxes, emails,
phone calls and communications of every type demanding the release of
Antonio, Ren�, Gerardo, Fernando and Ram�n.�

�Their immediate release must be the main consequence of the historic
step taken by the Atlanta judges, whose ruling � totally adhering to
the Constitution and other laws of that country � was demonstrative
of the dignity, decorum and professionalism of the three judges, who
merit all our respect.

�The decision of this court,� he indicated, �is the result of the
efforts of a group of U.S. lawyers, and the solidarity of numerous
people, many of them incorporated into solidarity groups has also had
weight in that.

�In no way is the finding a consequence of any action against the
United States by the Cuban government. The judges who analyzed the
case are not agents of our country, or revolutionaries, or
sympathizers with the Cuban Revolution. In the document that they
presented in an elegant language, they define their distance in
relation to Cuba,� Alarc�n noted, going on to point out that the
Miami mafia is already accusing and insulting those professionals,
believing that they have a favorable position towards Cuba.

�Our compatriots,� he recalled, �were fighting against terrorist
groups openly operating in Miami, with the indulgence, support and
protection of the U.S. government. Thus the case of the Five is
closely related to the backing given by Washington to terrorists like
Luis Posada Carriles. One of the merits of the Atlanta Court of
Appeals document is precisely to include an account of acts of
terrorism against Cuba, among them those executed by Posada Carriles.

The president of the Cuban Parliament explained that the U.S.
Attorney in Florida has just informed the Miami Herald that they are
considering a retrial for the Five next year. "Let�s see if they
dare, because now it is going to be very hard to prevent a lot of
interest in that trial, which could turn into a kind of Nuremberg for
the fascist government of the United States, its terrorists and their
buddies,� commented Alarc�n.

Coining Gerardo�s expression on the finding of the Atlanta Court of
Appeals, the parliamentary leader said that it could be concluded
that the ball is in the White House field and our hit is going to be
a homerun with bases full with the first pitch.

Alarc�n was speaking in the Festival�s international press center
based in the Arauco Suites Hotel. The mothers and wives of the Five
likewise participated in the meeting and responded to journalists�
questions.

� Reiterates in a press conference that in line with the Atlanta
Court ruling, they should be released immediately

Assembly of People�s Power, today asked participants in the 16th
World Festival of Youth and Students to raise their voices to demand

Antonio Guerrero, Fernando Gonz�lez, Gerardo Hern�ndez, Ram�n
Laba�ino and Ren� Gonz�lez never committed the crimes for which they

holding kidnapped five anti-terrorist combatants; that the U.S.

�Their immediate release must be the main consequence of the historic
step taken by the Atlanta judges, whose ruling � totally adhering to

closely related to the backing given by Washington to terrorists like

The president of the Cuban Parliament explained that the U.S.
Attorney in Florida has just informed the Miami Herald that they are
considering a retrial for the Five next year. "Let�s see if they
dare, because now it is going to be very hard to prevent a lot of
interest in that trial, which could turn into a kind of Nuremberg for
the fascist government of the United States, its terrorists and their
buddies,� commented Alarc�n.

Appeals, the parliamentary leader said that it could be concluded
that the ball is in the White House field and our hit is going to be
a homerun with bases full with the first pitch.

Alarc�n was speaking in the Festival�s international press center
based in the Arauco Suites Hotel. The mothers and wives of the Five
likewise participated in the meeting and responded to journalists�
questions.

Post ID:3763
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2005-08-16 14:20:58
Subject:ProLibertad Web Blog/Sept. 8th Tito Kayak!!
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
http://www.ProLibertadweb.com
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________________

DOWNLOAD THE AUGUST EDITION OF EL COQUI LIBRE; ProLibertad's newsletter:
http://www.prolibertadweb.com/eclAugust2005.pdf
_______________________________________________________________________________

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign NEEDS to hear from you!!  We have created a 
new web blog so that we can hear your opinions, input and ideas!!

Join the conversation, create a conversation, we need to hear from you:
http://www.prolibertadweb.com/ProLibFreedomBlog/
_______________________________________________________________________________

THURSDAY SEPTEMBER 8TH AT 9AM!!  JUSTICE FOR TITO KAYAK!!

Join ProLibertad, Ismael Guadalupe Ortiz (Long time Vieques Activist), and
the friends of Tito Kayak in NYC, as we support our brother Alberto �Tito
Kayak� DeJesus!!

Tito Kayak, a Puerto Rican environmentalist and civil disobedient, was
arrested on Monday June 13th, 2005 for  attempting to lower the United
Nations flag and replacing it with the Puerto Rican flag; this was an
another attempt to call attention to the colonial condition of Puerto Rico
and to the contamination on the island of Vieques!!

As many of you remember, Tito Kayak was responsible for hanging the Puerto
Rican and Vieques flags from the Statue of Liberty on November 2001.  Tito
was sentenced to jail for this act of civil disobedience and served his time
in New York City and Puerto Rico.

This latest civil disobedience took place during the United Nations
De-Colonization Hearings, as a delegation from Puerto Rico and throughout
the United States testified for the liberation of Puerto Rico from U.S.
colonialism.

Tito was released from prison on Tuesday June 14th; Tito has a hearing on
Thursday Sept. 8th!!  Tito could be facing 3-7 years for his endangerment
charge and 90 days for trespassing!!

Tito needs our support!!  Take the day off from Work!!  We have to pack the
court house and make sure that this brother receives justice!!

Thursday Sept. 8th at 9am
100 Centre St. Manhattan Criminal Court
Subway: 4, 5, 6, J, M to Chambers St./Brooklyn Bridge; A, C, E to Chambers
St.; R, N to Canal St.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Post ID:3765
Sender:"FreetheCuban5 LibertadparalosCinco" <freethecuban5@...>
Post Date/Time:2005-08-16 22:41:54
Subject:Aug. 30th and New Blog
Message:

The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
http://www.freethecuban5.com
Freethecuban5@...
Free the Cuban 5 Hotline: 718-601-4751

*******************************************************************************
Tuesday August 30th at 7:30pm
The Brecht Forum 451 West St. NYC
Phone: 212-242-4201

IF YOU MISSED MISSION AGAINST TERROR IN JUNE AND JULY, THEN JOIN US IN
AUGUST!!

Mission Against Terror (Directors Bernie Dwyer and Roberto Ruiz Rebo/ 48
minutes/2004) tells the story of the 5 Cubans, who are currently imprisoned
in U.S. jails because they were working for to expose ultra-right terrorist
groups in Miami and stop them from carrying out violent actions against the
Cuban people.

This film screening is a part of the Brecht Forum's Black August Film
Series!!  http://www.brechtforum.org

*******************************************************************************
The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5 has created a new Web blog 
for folks to communicate, share information and talk about our work to free 
the Cuban 5!!

Join the movement and conversation; let us engage in a Battle of Ideas:
http://www.freethecuban5.com/Freethe5/

*******************************************************************************
Sign the Cuban 5 Petition "Family Visitation Petition" prepared by the
Jericho Movement!!

Sign the Petition and get your friends and family to do so as well.  Also,
do not forget to send a letter to Attorney Alberto Gonzalez!!  Go to our
National Visa Campaign Page on our website and send out your support
letter!!

IT IS EXTREMELY IMPORTANT THAT WE KEEP THE PRESSURE UP ON U.S.
ATTORNEY GENERAL ALBERTO GONZALEZ; SEND THE LETTER OUT AND
FORWARD IT THROUGH YOUR EMAIL ADDRESS BOOKS!!

http://www.petitiononline.com/cuban5/petition.html





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign NEEDS to hear from you!!  We have created a
new web blog so that we can hear your opinions, input and ideas!!  Our  
questions to the public are:

1. How can we re-popularize the work to free the Puerto Rican Political 
prisoners?
2. How do we attract more youth to our work?
3. What can you do to make the freedom of our prisoners happen?

Chime in, Join the conversation, create a conversation, we need to hear from 
you:
http://www.prolibertadweb.com/ProLibFreedomBlog/

Sept. 8th for Tito kayak and Friday A special event/reception for TITO 
KAYAK, ISMAEL GUADALUPE AND FORMER PRICAN
POLITICAL PRISONER ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON!!

THURSDAY SEPTEMBER 8TH AT 9AM!!  JUSTICE FOR TITO KAYAK!!
Thursday Sept. 8th at 9am
100 Centre St. Manhattan Criminal Court
Subway: 4, 5, 6, J, M to Chambers St./Brooklyn Bridge; A, C, E to Chambers
St.; R, N to Canal St.

Join ProLibertad, Ismael Guadalupe Ortiz (Long time Vieques Activist), and
the friends of Tito Kayak in NYC, as we support our brother Alberto �Tito
Kayak� DeJesus!!

Tito Kayak, a Puerto Rican environmentalist and civil disobedient, was
arrested on Monday June 13th, 2005 for  attempting to lower the United
Nations flag and replacing it with the Puerto Rican flag; this was an
another attempt to call attention to the colonial condition of Puerto Rico
and to the contamination on the island of Vieques!!

Thursday Sept. 8th!!  Tito could be facing 3-7 years for his endangerment

Tito needs our support!!  Take the day off from Work!!  We have to pack the
court house and make sure that this brother receives justice!!
_______________________________________________________________________________

The Puerto Rican Movement: The Struggle Continues!!

Friday September 9th, 2005 at 6:30pm at
St. Mary�s Episcopal Church 521 w126th St.
(between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue)
Take the 1 or 9 train to W125th St. and Broadway

$5 donation (no one will be turned away)

Join the ProLibertad Freedom Campaign for a night of dialogue and 
conversation with
Vieques Activist/Environmentalist Tito Kayak, long time Vieques Activist 
Ismael Guadalupe
and former Puerto Rican Political Prisoner Antonio Camacho Negron!!

We will be discussing the Vieques struggle, the Puerto Rican independence 
movement,
and the work to free the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners!!

Join us and learn how you can make freedom and liberation happen!!  We 
encourage
all PEOPLES to attend and learn about the Puerto Rican National Liberation 
Struggle!!

Light refreshments and beverages will be provided!!

Subject:Sept. 8-9 for Tito Kayak
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
http://www.ProLibertadweb.com
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________________

DOWNLOAD THE AUGUST EDITION OF EL COQUI LIBRE; ProLibertad's newsletter:
http://www.prolibertadweb.com/eclAugust2005.pdf
_______________________________________________________________________________

Join ProLibertad on Thursday Sept. 8th and Friday Sept. 9th!!  Thursday
Sept. 8th for Tito kayak and Friday A special event/reception for former
Puerto Rican/Vieques Political Prisoners TITO KAYAK, ISMAEL GUADALUPE AND
ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON!!

THURSDAY SEPTEMBER 8TH AT 9AM!!  JUSTICE FOR TITO KAYAK!!
Thursday Sept. 8th at 9am
100 Centre St. Manhattan Criminal Court
Subway: 4, 5, 6, J, M to Chambers St./Brooklyn Bridge; A, C, E to Chambers
St.; R, N to Canal St.

Join ProLibertad, Ismael Guadalupe Ortiz (Long time Vieques Activist), and
the friends of Tito Kayak in NYC, as we support our brother Alberto �Tito
Kayak� DeJesus!!

Tito Kayak, a Puerto Rican environmentalist and civil disobedient, was
arrested on Monday June 13th, 2005 for  attempting to lower the United
Nations flag and replacing it with the Puerto Rican flag; this was an
another attempt to call attention to the colonial condition of Puerto Rico
and to the contamination on the island of Vieques!!

As many of you remember, Tito Kayak was responsible for hanging the Puerto
Rican and Vieques flags from the Statue of Liberty on November 2001.  Tito
was sentenced to jail for this act of civil disobedience and served his time
in New York City and Puerto Rico.

This latest civil disobedience took place during the United Nations
De-Colonization Hearings, as a delegation from Puerto Rico and throughout
the United States testified for the liberation of Puerto Rico from U.S.
colonialism.  Tito was released from prison on Tuesday June 14th; Tito has a
hearing on
Thursday Sept. 8th!!  Tito could be facing 3-7 years for his endangerment
charge and 90 days for trespassing!!

Tito needs our support!!  Take the day off from Work!!  We have to pack the
court house and make sure that this brother receives justice!!
_______________________________________________________________________________

The Puerto Rican Movement: The Struggle Continues!!

Friday September 9th, 2005 at 6:30pm at
St. Mary�s Episcopal Church 521 w126th St.
(between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue)
Take the 1 or 9 train to W125th St. and Broadway

$5 donation (no one will be turned away)

Join the ProLibertad Freedom Campaign for a night of dialogue and
conversation with Vieques Activist/Environmentalist Tito Kayak, long time 
Vieques Activist
Ismael Guadalupe and former Puerto Rican Political Prisoner Antonio Camacho 
Negron!!

We will be discussing the Vieques struggle, the Puerto Rican independence
movement, and the work to free the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners!!

Join us and learn how you can make freedom and liberation happen!!  We
encourage all PEOPLES to attend and learn about the Puerto Rican National 
Liberation
Struggle!!

Light refreshments and beverages will be provided!





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Post ID:3777
Sender:"FreetheCuban5 LibertadparalosCinco" <freethecuban5@...>
Post Date/Time:2005-08-25 14:39:15
Subject:Aug. 30th Mission Against Terror
Message:

The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
http://www.freethecuban5.com
Freethecuban5@...
Free the Cuban 5 Hotline: 718-601-4751

*******************************************************************************
Tuesday August 30th at 7:30pm
The Brecht Forum 451 West St. NYC
Phone: 212-242-4201

IF YOU MISSED MISSION AGAINST TERROR IN JUNE AND JULY, THEN JOIN US IN
AUGUST!!

Mission Against Terror (Directors Bernie Dwyer and Roberto Ruiz Rebo/ 48
minutes/2004) tells the story of the 5 Cubans, who are currently imprisoned
in U.S. jails because they were working for to expose ultra-right terrorist
groups in Miami and stop them from carrying out violent actions against the
Cuban people.

This film screening is a part of the Brecht Forum's Black August Film
Series!!  http://www.brechtforum.org

*******************************************************************************

Sign the Cuban 5 Petition "Family Visitation Petition" prepared by the
Jericho Movement!!

Sign the Petition and get your friends and family to do so as well.  Also,
do not forget to send a letter to Attorney Alberto Gonzalez!!  Go to our
National Visa Campaign Page on our website and send out your support
letter!!

IT IS EXTREMELY IMPORTANT THAT WE KEEP THE PRESSURE UP ON U.S. ATTORNEY
GENERAL ALBERTO GONZALEZ; SEND THE LETTER OUT AND FORWARD IT THROUGH YOUR
EMAIL ADDRESS BOOKS!!

http://www.petitiononline.com/cuban5/petition.html

*******************************************************************************

This is a message from Prensa Latina, August 17, from Ram�n Laba�ino

Ramon Laba�ino, one of the Five anti-terrorist Cubans unjustly
imprisoned in the United States, sent a message of appreciation to
the Cuban people and friends around the world for their solidarity,
after the positive decision of the Court of Appeals.

To all the brothers and sisters who in one way or another have
helped in the cause of the Five: Congratulations, because this has
been a triumph of justice, but of solidarity as well, said Laba�ino
in his message published in the Rebel Youth (Juventud Rebelde)
newspaper.

The past August 9, the Court of Appeals of Atlanta overturned the
sentences that weighed upon him and his comrades Gerardo Hern�ndez,
Antonio Guerrero, Fernando Gonz�lez and Ren� Gonz�lez, in prison
since 1998.

The judges who revised the case also ordered a new trial outside of
Miami, bastion of the Cuban counterrevolution abroad.

The Atlanta decision was preceded by a decision of a group of
experts from the United Nations, which recognized the illegality of
the detentions and the trial, which followed in the city of Miami,
as they are also known, and it called for remedies to the case.

"These are now two big blows for those who are trying to keep us
imprisoned, that from the Working Group on Arbitrary Detentions of
the UN, which was categorical in its conclusion, and now the 11th
Circuit gave its verdict," said Laba�ino, who [was] sentenced to
life plus 18 years.

In spite of never losing his hope, the economist feels more
optimistic than ever especially after reading the 93 pages of the
judges' decision and he notes how sweeping was their response,
explained his wife Elizabeth Palmeiro, after a short visit with him
in the prison. It is very difficult to appeal something so well
argued o full of ethics, as he told his wife during their visit.

He also said that they "were certain that outside of Miami the
outcome would be different and Atlanta is the proof."


Members of the National Committee to Free the Cuban Five visited
Gerardo Hernandez

On Saturday August 20, we visited Gerardo Hernandez at the U.S.
Penitentiary in Adelanto California. We found him to be in good
spirits with his usual sincerity and sense of humor.  Gerardo of
course is closely following the new developments in their case and
is cautiously optimistic about the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals
ruling that was issued on August 9.

On behalf of the Cuban 5, Gerardo sends from the prison his warmest
regards to all of the Cuban solidarity activists in the United
States and around the world who have been working so hard on the
case of the Five. He told us, "It would not have been the same
without the support we have received from groups and individuals who
have been instrumental in raising awareness of the injustice of our
incarceration"

Because of a dramatic increase in the amount of mail Gerardo is
receiving, particularly after this latest development in the case,
he wants everyone to know how deeply he appreciates this out pouring
of support. He told us to let you know that it would be difficult to
respond to each of you on an individual basis at this time.

While the recent ruling of the court of appeals marks a significant
break in the case of the Cuban Five, Gerardo is conscious that the
struggle for their freedom will not end until the day they all step
back onto Cuban soil. At the end of our visit, he reminded us once
again to send his thanks and solidarity to all of you.

Alicia Jrapko and Bill Hackwell
National Committee to Free the Cuban Five





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This is a message from Prensa Latina, August 17, from Ram�n Laba�ino

Ramon Laba�ino, one of the Five anti-terrorist Cubans unjustly
imprisoned in the United States, sent a message of appreciation to
the Cuban people and friends around the world for their solidarity,
after the positive decision of the Court of Appeals.

To all the brothers and sisters who in one way or another have
helped in the cause of the Five: Congratulations, because this has
been a triumph of justice, but of solidarity as well, said Laba�ino
in his message published in the Rebel Youth (Juventud Rebelde)
newspaper.

The past August 9, the Court of Appeals of Atlanta overturned the
sentences that weighed upon him and his comrades Gerardo Hern�ndez,
Antonio Guerrero, Fernando Gonz�lez and Ren� Gonz�lez, in prison
since 1998.

Miami, bastion of the Cuban counterrevolution abroad.

in the prison. It is very difficult to appeal something so well

Gerardo Hernandez

Alicia Jrapko and Bill Hackwell

Post ID:3779
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2005-08-26 16:12:20
Subject:Join: Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners Campaign
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
http://www.ProLibertadweb.com
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________________

Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners!!

History has shown us that the power of the people, active and in motion,
frees political prisoners. It was our united cry for freedom, international
support and consistent national work for more than three decades that
pressured President Carter to free the 4 Nationalist Political Prisoners in
1978 and President Clinton to grant clemency to 12 of the Puerto Rican
Political Prisoners in 1999. Today, however, three Puerto Rican Political
Prisoners, Haydee Beltran, Oscar Lopez Rivera, and Carlos Alberto Torres
remain in U.S. jails serving punitive and excessive sentences for fighting
for the independence and self-determination of Puerto Rico; a colony of the
United States since 1898. Adding your voice to the cry for freedom, justice
and human rights now can insure that our call will be heard once again and
will make an important contribution to obtaining justice for these freedom
fighters.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign makes a call to all people who love freedom
and justice to take up the challenge presented by �Millions for the Puerto
Rican Political Prisoners!� Campaign. Our goal is to re-energize the
campaign to obtain the unconditional release of the Puerto Rican Political
Prisoners by collecting one million signatures calling for their
unconditional release. In June of 2006, we will present the petitions
collected to the International Community during the annual hearings of the
United Nations Special Committee on De-colonization.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling on all freedom and justice
loving people to support this campaign. We propose to identify 1000
organizations and individuals, nationally and internationally, to sponsor
the campaign and to commit to collecting signatures within their
organization, community, school, church, etc. Sponsoring organizations and
individuals will receive a packet with ProLibertad literature and 100
petitions; each petition has 10 spaces for signatures. By working with 1000
organizations, each taking 100 petitions at 10 signatures per page, we will
reach our goal of Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners.

This campaign will show the international community that the movement to
free the Puerto Rican Political is alive and thriving. This campaign will
allow us to educate, organize and mobilize people throughout the world. You
can help us make this just goal a reality! We call upon you to become an
active part of the �Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners�
Campaign!

Throughout the coming year ProLibertad will be organizing petition drives,
community forums and other events to promote the campaign. Organizations and
individuals will be invited to help in the collection of signatures, the
dissemination of literature and to support events. We will encourage
sponsoring organizations to hold their own activities and initiatives during
the year and will help to publicize, mobilize and provide support.

All sponsoring organizations and individuals who sign onto this campaign
will be listed in all the Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners
Campaign literature and media outreach.

To join our campaign contact us via email ProLibertad@..., or call
us at Bronx 718-601-4751, Manhattan 212-927-9065, or New Jersey
201-435-3244. Send us your address and contact information and we will send
you the �Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners� Packet and add
you to our list to keep you updates on campaign developments.

Your organizational or individual donations are also needed to make the
�Millions for the Puerto Rican Prisoners� Campaign a success. Tax-deductible
donations may be sent to: IFCO/ProLibertad, 402 West 145th Street, New York,
New York 10033. Please indicate Millions in 2006 in the memo section of your
check or money order.

Our Cry For Freedom And Justice Must Be Heard!
The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Campaign literature and media outreach.

To join our campaign contact us via email ProLibertad@..., or call
us at Bronx 718-601-4751, Manhattan 212-927-9065, or New Jersey
201-435-3244. Send us your address and contact information and we will send
you the �Millions for the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners� Packet and add
you to our list to keep you updates on campaign developments.

Your organizational or individual donations are also needed to make the
�Millions for the Puerto Rican Prisoners� Campaign a success. Tax-deductible
donations may be sent to: IFCO/ProLibertad, 402 West 145th Street, New York,
New York 10033. Please indicate Millions in 2006 in the memo section of your
check or money order.

Our Cry For Freedom And Justice Must Be Heard!
The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign

the friends of Tito Kayak in NYC, as we support our brother Alberto �Tito

As many of you remember, Tito Kayak was responsible for hanging the Puerto
Rican and Vieques flags from the Statue of Liberty on November 2001.  Tito
was sentenced to jail for this act of civil disobedience and served his time
in New York City and Puerto Rico.

This latest civil disobedience took place during the United Nations
De-Colonization Hearings, as a delegation from Puerto Rico and throughout
the United States testified for the liberation of Puerto Rico from U.S.
colonialism.  Tito was released from prison on Tuesday June 14th; Tito has a
hearing on Thursday Sept. 8th!!  Tito could be facing 3-7 years for his 
endangerment
charge and 90 days for trespassing!!

Tito needs our support!!  Take the day off from Work!!  We have to pack the
court house and make sure that this brother receives justice!!
_______________________________________________________________________________

The Puerto Rican Movement: The Struggle Continues!!

Friday September 9th, 2005 at 6:30pm at
St. Mary�s Episcopal Church 521 w126th St.
(between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue)
Take the 1 or 9 train to W125th St. and Broadway

$5 donation (no one will be turned away)

Join the ProLibertad Freedom Campaign for a night of dialogue and
conversation with Vieques Activist/Environmentalist Tito Kayak, long time
Vieques Activist Ismael Guadalupe and former Puerto Rican Political Prisoner 
Antonio Camacho
Negron!!

We will be discussing the Vieques struggle, the Puerto Rican independence
movement, and the work to free the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners!!

Join us and learn how you can make freedom and liberation happen!!  We
encourage all PEOPLES to attend and learn about the Puerto Rican National
Liberation Struggle!!

Light refreshments and beverages will be provided!

Post ID:3790
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2005-09-08 13:55:43
Subject:UPDATE: Oct. 11th Justice for Tito Kayak!!
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
http://www.ProLibertadweb.com
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________________

DOWNLOAD THE SEPTEMBER EDITION OF EL COQUI LIBRE; ProLibertad's newsletter:
http://www.prolibertadweb.com/eclSeptember2005.pdf
_______________________________________________________________________________

1.  FIRST: An update on Tito Kayak's New trial
2.  REMINDER: The Puerto Rican Movement: the Struggle Continues Friday Sept. 
9th
    (Bottom Message)
_______________________________________________________________________________

JUSTICE FOR TITO KAYAK!!
TUESDAY OCTOBER 11TH, 2005 AT 9AM
MANHATTAN CRIMINAL COURT 100 CENTRE ST.
Subway: 4, 5, 6, J, M to Chambers St./Brooklyn Bridge; A, C, E to Chambers 
St.; R, N to Canal St.

Join ProLibertad and the friends of Tito Kayak in NYC, as we support our 
brother Alberto �Tito Kayak� DeJesus!

Tito Kayak, a Puerto Rican environmentalist and civil disobedient, was 
arrested on Monday June 13th, 2005 for  attempting to lower the United 
Nations flag and replacing it with the Puerto Rican flag; this was an 
another attempt to call attention to the colonial condition of Puerto Rico 
and to the contamination on the island of Vieques!!  As many of you 
remember, Tito Kayak was responsible for hanging the Puerto Rican and 
Vieques flags from the Statue of Liberty on November 2001.  Tito was 
sentenced to jail for this act of civil disobedience and served his time in 
New York City and Puerto Rico.

Tito�s hearing was scheduled for Thursday Sept. 8th at 9am; ProLibertad, the 
Friends of Tito Kayak and Long time Vieques activist Ismael Guadalupe 
supported Tito as his trial was scheduled for Tuesday October 11th, 2005 at 
9am!!

Tito is facing a Class B misdemeanor charge of trespassing; if found guilty 
he will have to serve 90 days in jail!!  Tito�s felony charge of Reckless 
endangerment was dropped!!  Tito should not serve one day in jail!!

TAKE THE DAY OFF FROM WORK!!
SUPPORT TITO KAYAK!!
_______________________________________________________________________________

The Puerto Rican Movement: The Struggle Continues!!

Friday September 9th, 2005 at 6:30pm at
St. Mary�s Episcopal Church 521 w126th St.
(between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue)
Take the 1 or 9 train to W125th St. and Broadway

$5 donation (no one will be turned away)

Join the ProLibertad Freedom Campaign for a night of dialogue and
conversation with Vieques Activist/Environmentalist Tito Kayak, long time
Vieques Activist Ismael Guadalupe and former Puerto Rican Political Prisoner
Antonio Camacho Negron!!

We will be discussing the Vieques struggle, the Puerto Rican independence
movement, and the work to free the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners!!

Join us and learn how you can make freedom and liberation happen!!  We
encourage all PEOPLES to attend and learn about the Puerto Rican National
Liberation Struggle!!

Light refreshments and beverages will be provided!

New York City and Puerto Rico.

Tito�s hearing was scheduled for Thursday Sept. 8th at 9am; ProLibertad, the
Friends of Tito Kayak and Long time Vieques activist Ismael Guadalupe
supported Tito as his trial was scheduled for Tuesday October 11th, 2005 at
9am!!

Tito is facing a Class B misdemeanor charge of trespassing; if found guilty
he will have to serve 90 days in jail!!  Tito�s felony charge of Reckless
endangerment was dropped!!  Tito should not serve one day in jail!!

TAKE THE DAY OFF FROM WORK!!
SUPPORT TITO KAYAK!!

brother Alberto �Tito Kayak� DeJesus!

Tito Kayak, a Puerto Rican environmentalist and civil disobedient, was
arrested on Monday June 13th, 2005 for  attempting to lower the United
Nations flag and replacing it with the Puerto Rican flag; this was an
another attempt to call attention to the colonial condition of Puerto Rico
and to the contamination on the island of Vieques!!  As many of you
remember, Tito Kayak was responsible for hanging the Puerto Rican and
Vieques flags from the Statue of Liberty on November 2001.  Tito was
sentenced to jail for this act of civil disobedience and served his time in
New York City and Puerto Rico.

Tito�s hearing was scheduled for Thursday Sept. 8th at 9am; ProLibertad, the
Friends of Tito Kayak and Long time Vieques activist Ismael Guadalupe

9am!!

endangerment was dropped!!  Tito should not serve one day in jail!!

_______________________________________________________________________________

Despierta Boricua is a weekly fifteen-minute Radio segment produced for WBAI
99.5 FM Friday Morning Wake UP Call by The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign.
Despierta Boricua airs at 6:45am, but is subject to re-scheduling depending
on the Station�s needs.

This week�s segment (Friday Sept. 16th) will feature a Vieques update with
Roberto Rabin of the Committee for the Rescue and Development of Vieques
Puerto Rico.  We will be talking about the movement to gentrify Vieques,
the US Navy's refusal to decontaminate, and other Committee Projects.

If you have any questions, comments, or ideas for Despierta Boricua segment 
then post a
message on our web blog at http://www.prolibertadweb.com/ProLibFreedomBlog/

Tune in every week to Despierta Boricua, whether you receive a reminder or
not, 6:45am WBAI 99.5fm or via web stream, for those of you outside of NYC,
http://www.wbai.org
______________________________________________________________________________

JUSTICE FOR TITO KAYAK!!
TUESDAY OCTOBER 11TH, 2005 AT 9AM
MANHATTAN CRIMINAL COURT 100 CENTRE ST.
Subway: 4, 5, 6, J, M to Chambers St./Brooklyn Bridge; A, C, E to Chambers
St.; R, N to Canal St.
